name: Nicolaus Copernicus
bio: Renaissance astronomer who placed the Sun—not Earth—at the center, launching a profound rethinking of celestial mechanics and physics.

name: Galileo Galilei
bio: Pioneer of kinematics and telescopic astronomy; articulated inertia, studied falling bodies, and defended heliocentrism with quantitative experiments.

name: Johannes Kepler
bio: Derived planetary laws of motion from Tycho’s data, uniting precise observation with physical causes for celestial orbits.

name: Christiaan Huygens
bio: Formulated the wave theory of light and discovered Saturn’s moon Titan; advanced pendulum clocks and mechanics.

name: René Descartes
bio: Developed analytic geometry and mechanistic physics ideas; helped set mathematical foundations for later physical theories.

name: Blaise Pascal
bio: Linked pressure to altitude, studied vacuums, and co-founded probability—shaping experimental physics and mathematics.

name: Robert Hooke
bio: Elasticity’s namesake; improved microscopes, mapped the Moon, and advanced experimental method at the Royal Society.

name: Isaac Newton
bio: Unified celestial and terrestrial physics via laws of motion and universal gravitation; founded calculus and modern optics.

name: Gottfried Wilhelm Leibniz
bio: Co-invented calculus and argued for energy-like quantities in dynamics that influenced later physical formalism.

name: Edmond Halley
bio: Predicted periodic returns of the comet bearing his name and supported Newton’s _Principia_ publication.

name: Ole Rømer
bio: First to measure the finite speed of light using eclipses of Jupiter’s moon Io.

name: Henry Cavendish
bio: Measured Earth’s density via torsion balance; isolated hydrogen and studied electrostatics quantitatively.

name: Charles-Augustin de Coulomb
bio: Established the inverse-square law of electric force with torsion balance experiments.

name: Joseph-Louis Lagrange
bio: Formulated analytical mechanics and the Lagrangian, a cornerstone of modern theoretical physics.

name: Pierre-Simon Laplace
bio: Cast gravitation and celestial motion into probability and differential equations; anticipated the nebular hypothesis.

name: André-Marie Ampère
bio: Unified electricity and magnetism experimentally; the ampere honors his foundational work in electrodynamics.

name: Augustin-Jean Fresnel
bio: Explained diffraction and polarization, firmly establishing light’s wave nature.

name: Michael Faraday
bio: Discovered electromagnetic induction and field concepts; his experiments fueled modern electrical technology.

name: Georg Ohm
bio: Quantified the relation between voltage, current, and resistance—Ohm’s law.

name: Sadi Carnot
bio: Laid thermodynamics’ foundations by analyzing heat engines and reversible cycles.

name: Joseph Fourier
bio: Showed that functions decompose into trigonometric series, enabling heat equation solutions and spectral methods across physics.

name: Carl Friedrich Gauss
bio: Advanced potential theory, least squares, and magnetism; a universal figure linking math with physical measurement.

name: James Clerk Maxwell
bio: Unified electricity, magnetism, and light into Maxwell’s equations—heralding modern field theory and relativity.

name: Ludwig Boltzmann
bio: Founded statistical mechanics, linking microscopic ensembles to macroscopic entropy and thermodynamics.

name: J. Willard Gibbs
bio: Created modern thermodynamics and vector analysis; chemical potentials and phase rules bear his imprint.

name: Hermann von Helmholtz
bio: Linked energy conservation to physiology and acoustics; reframed optics and perception quantitatively.

name: Gustav Kirchhoff
bio: Formulated circuit laws and, with Bunsen, founded spectral analysis crucial to astrophysics.

name: Heinrich Hertz
bio: Generated and detected radio waves, confirming Maxwell’s theory; the hertz unit honors him.

name: Albert A. Michelson
bio: Precision interferometrist; the Michelson–Morley experiment probed the speed of light’s invariance.

name: Henri Becquerel
bio: Discovered natural radioactivity via uranium salts’ spontaneous emissions on photographic plates.

name: Marie Curie
bio: Pioneered radioactivity; isolated polonium and radium; first person to win two Nobel Prizes.

name: Pierre Curie
bio: Co-discovered radioactivity’s properties; work on piezoelectricity and crystal symmetry was foundational.

name: Ernest Rutherford
bio: Father of nuclear physics; discovered the nucleus and proposed the planetary atomic model.

name: Max Planck
bio: Quantized energy to resolve blackbody radiation, launching quantum theory.

name: Albert Einstein
bio: Formulated special and general relativity; explained the photoelectric effect and Brownian motion.

name: Satyendra Nath Bose
bio: Co-founded quantum statistics; bosons and Bose–Einstein condensation bear his name.

name: Enrico Fermi
bio: Built the first controlled nuclear reactor; unified theory and experiment across nuclear and particle physics.

name: Werner Heisenberg
bio: Founded matrix mechanics and the uncertainty principle; central to quantum foundations.

name: Paul Dirac
bio: Unified quantum mechanics and special relativity; predicted antimatter through the Dirac equation.

name: Erwin Schrödinger
bio: Wave mechanics pioneer; the Schrödinger equation underpins non-relativistic quantum theory.

name: Wolfgang Pauli
bio: Formulated the exclusion principle, explaining electron shell structure and matter’s stability.

name: Max Born
bio: Interpreted the wavefunction probabilistically; advanced lattice dynamics and crystal physics.

name: Louis de Broglie
bio: Proposed matter waves, unifying particle and wave descriptions in quantum mechanics.

name: Niels Bohr
bio: Quantized atomic model; complementarity and Copenhagen interpretation shaped quantum thought.

name: Lise Meitner
bio: Explained nuclear fission’s physics with Frisch; an unsung architect of nuclear-era insights.

name: Abdus Salam
bio: Co-developed electroweak unification with Weinberg and Glashow, earning the Nobel Prize.

name: Chen-Ning Yang
bio: With Lee, showed parity is violated in weak interactions; advanced gauge theories.

name: Tsung-Dao Lee
bio: Co-discovered parity violation in weak interactions, reshaping particle physics symmetries.

name: Eugene Wigner
bio: Brought group theory to quantum mechanics; clarified nuclear structure and symmetries.

name: Lev Landau
bio: Created Landau theory of phase transitions and Fermi liquids; towering theorist across condensed matter.

name: Andrei Sakharov
bio: Plasma physicist and dissident; advanced controlled fusion and championed human rights.

name: John Stewart Bell
bio: Derived Bell’s theorem, testing locality and realism in quantum mechanics.

name: Richard Feynman
bio: Path integrals and QED architect; legendary teacher who bridged fundamentals and applications.

name: Julian Schwinger
bio: Co-developed quantum electrodynamics with covariant methods and renormalization.

name: Sin-Itiro Tomonaga
bio: Recast QED with relativistic consistency, sharing the Nobel with Schwinger and Feynman.

name: Stephen Hawking
bio: Revealed black hole radiation and linked gravity, quantum theory, and thermodynamics.

name: Roger Penrose
bio: Proved singularity theorems and advanced twistor theory; 2020 Nobel for black hole formation.

name: Peter Higgs
bio: Proposed the mass-giving Higgs mechanism; discovery of the boson confirmed it.

name: Carl D. Anderson
bio: Discovered the positron in cosmic rays, verifying antimatter experimentally.

name: Subrahmanyan Chandrasekhar
bio: Explained stellar evolution limits (Chandrasekhar mass), pivotal to white dwarfs and black holes.

name: Edwin Hubble
bio: Showed expanding universe via galaxy redshifts; set extragalactic astronomy’s scale.

name: Emmy Noether
bio: Linked symmetries to conservation laws—an indispensable pillar of modern theoretical physics.

name: John Archibald Wheeler
bio: Coined “black hole”; advanced nuclear fission theory and quantum foundations.

name: Fritz Zwicky
bio: Inferred dark matter in galaxy clusters; innovator of supernova and neutron-star ideas.

name: Hans Bethe
bio: Explained stellar nucleosynthesis (pp chain, CNO cycle) and shaped nuclear theory.

name: Isidor Isaac Rabi
bio: Developed molecular beam magnetic resonance, foundational for NMR and MRI.

name: Charles H. Townes
bio: Co-invented the maser and laser, transforming spectroscopy and technology.

name: Felix Bloch
bio: Explained electrons in crystals; nuclear magnetic resonance pioneer.

name: Edward M. Purcell
bio: Co-discovered 21-cm hydrogen line; advanced NMR in solids and liquids.

name: John Bardeen
bio: Two-time Nobel laureate for the transistor and BCS superconductivity theory.

name: William Shockley
bio: Co-invented the transistor; later work influenced semiconductor physics and technology.

name: William Henry Bragg
bio: With his son, created X-ray crystallography—resolving atomic structures of matter.

name: William Lawrence Bragg
bio: Youngest Nobel laureate in physics; co-founded X-ray crystallography’s methods.

name: Pyotr Kapitza
bio: Low-temperature experimentalist; discovered superfluidity in helium.

name: Igor Tamm
bio: Explained Cherenkov radiation with Frank and developed nuclear-theory advances.

name: Pavel Cherenkov
bio: Observed blue glow from particles faster than light in media—Cherenkov radiation.

name: Gerard ’t Hooft
bio: Renormalized non-Abelian gauge theories, cementing the Standard Model.

name: Martinus J. G. Veltman
bio: With ’t Hooft, proved renormalizability of electroweak theory.

name: David J. Gross
bio: Co-discovered asymptotic freedom in QCD; advanced string and field theory.

name: H. David Politzer
bio: Shared Nobel for asymptotic freedom, explaining quark interactions at high energies.

name: Frank Wilczek
bio: Asymptotic freedom co-discoverer; contributions span QCD, axions, and topological matter.

name: Edward Witten
bio: Leading string theorist; reframed quantum field theory with deep mathematical structures.

name: Russell A. Hulse
bio: Co-discovered the Hulse–Taylor binary pulsar, confirming gravitational-wave damping.

name: Joseph H. Taylor Jr.
bio: Shared Nobel for binary pulsar tests of general relativity.

name: Jim Peebles
bio: Shaped physical cosmology: CMB, structure formation, and dark-matter frameworks.

name: Michel Mayor
bio: With Queloz, found the first exoplanet orbiting a Sun-like star.

name: Didier Queloz
bio: Co-discovered 51 Pegasi b, igniting exoplanetary science.

name: John C. Mather
bio: COBE project leader; mapped CMB spectrum and anisotropy.

name: George F. Smoot
bio: COBE anisotropy co-discoverer, sharpening Big Bang cosmology.

name: Adam G. Riess
bio: Measured cosmic acceleration via supernovae; key to dark energy discovery.

name: Saul Perlmutter
bio: Led supernova searches revealing the accelerating universe.

name: Brian P. Schmidt
bio: Co-led observations that uncovered cosmic acceleration.

name: Vera Rubin
bio: Measured galaxy rotation curves, giving decisive evidence for dark matter.

name: Jocelyn Bell Burnell
bio: Discovered pulsars as a graduate student, opening a new window on compact objects.

name: Mildred Dresselhaus
bio: Transformed carbon science and nanomaterials; championed women in physics.

name: Donna Strickland
bio: Co-invented chirped-pulse amplification, enabling high-intensity ultrafast lasers.

name: Andrea Ghez
bio: Measured stellar orbits proving a supermassive black hole at the Milky Way’s center.

name: Kip S. Thorne
bio: Theorist of gravitation and astrophysics; LIGO co-founder and 2017 Nobel laureate.

name: Rainer Weiss
bio: Pioneered laser interferometry for LIGO, enabling direct detection of gravitational waves.

name: Barry C. Barish
bio: Led LIGO to detection; advanced large-scale experimental physics.
